You can use keyboard shortcuts to quickly accomplish many tasks in iTunes. To find the shortcuts for common commands, look in the iTunes menus, or use the table below as a reference. Many items in iTunes (for example, songs and column headings) also have contextual menus. To see a contextual menu, press the Control key and click the item. To perform an action, press the shortcut keys indicated below.

Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Crossfade Songs

Fade songs in and out, with no silence between songs. Drag the slider to change the amount of time it takes for the current song to fade out at the end and the new song to fade in.

Sound Enhancer

Change the music’s sound quality during playback. Drag the slider to increase or decrease the Sound Enhancer’s effect.

Sound Check

Play all music and video at the same volume level.

Play Movies and TV Shows

Play movies and TV shows in artwork viewer, a different part of the iTunes window, full screen, or in a separate window. If the visualizer is on and “Full screen with visuals” is selected, video in a playlist plays audio only.

Play Music Videos

Play music videos in artwork viewer, a different part of the iTunes window, full screen, or in a separate window. If the visualizer is on and “Full screen with visuals” is selected, video in a playlist plays audio only.

Audio Language

Change the default playback language.

Subtitle Language

Change the language used for movie subtitles and closed captions.

Play videos using standard definition version

Always play non-HD video, even if a high-definition version is available. You might want to choose this if you have an older computer that can’t play HD video well.

Show closed captioning when available

itns27553.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

iTunes Media folder location

To change where songs and other files you import into iTunes are located, click Change.

To change back to the original location for files ([home]/Music/iTunes), click Reset.

Keep iTunes Media folder organized

Automatically put imported music into folders for album and artist.

Copy files to iTunes Media folder when adding to library

Copy an item to the iTunes Media folder when you drag the item to the iTunes window or choose File > “Add to Library.”

If you want items to appear in iTunes but also remain in their original location, deselect this checkbox. For example, you can keep music imported from CDs on your computer’s hard disk, and save your video files on an external hard disk.

Pressing the Option key while dragging temporarily reverses the current checkbox setting.

Streaming Buffer Size

Change how much audio or video is downloaded before it starts to play. A larger buffer can help video play more smoothly. If you have a fast Internet connection, a smaller buffer can help the movie start playing more quickly.

Use iTunes for Internet playback

Use iTunes to play Internet radio stations, MP3s, and other audio files on the Internet.

Reset all dialog warnings

If you selected “Do not show this message again” in one or more dialogs (small windows with messages in them), clicking Reset makes the messages appear again, as if you’d just opened iTunes for the first time.

Reset iTunes Store cache

iTunes saves the store pages you visit on your computer in a temporary location called the “cache.” If you return later, iTunes can retrieve the page from the cache faster than getting it from the Internet.

If the content on a page seems outdated, you may want to reset the cache to make iTunes retrieve the latest version of the page. If you think a page is not opening properly, resetting the cache may help.

Keep Mini Player on top of all other windows

Keep the Mini Player (the iTunes window after you click the green zoom button) in front of all open windows, even while you use applications other than iTunes.

Keep movie window on top of all other windows

When playing video in a separate window, keep the movie window in front of all open windows, even while you use applications other than iTunes.

Display visualizer full screen

Show visual effects full screen instead of within the iTunes window.

itns27555.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Automatically check for available downloads

iTunes displays the number of items you previously purchased from the iTunes Store but didn’t download.

Automatically download prepurchased content

Automatically download items you pay for in advance, such as new episodes of a TV show you purchased with a Season Pass, as they become available. If multiple computers are authorized for your iTunes Store account, you can only set up one for automatic downloads.

Automatically download missing album artwork

Automatically add album artwork for music you import into iTunes from CDs or other sources. Artwork is already included with all music purchased from the iTunes Store.

Use full window for iTunes Store

Selecting this preference hides the lists on the left side of the iTunes window (Library, Store, and so on) when you enter the iTunes Store. To exit the iTunes Store when the lists are hidden, click the “X” at the upper left of the store window or press the Escape key on your keyboard.

If you use a screen reader, the lists can’t be hidden, even if you select this option.

Menu

Settings for

Choose the podcast you want these settings to apply to. If you want these settings to apply to all podcasts without their own settings, choose Podcast Defaults.

When new episodes are available

Episodes to keep

  • To keep each episode until you watch it and then automatically delete it, choose “All unplayed episodes.”

This menu isn’t available if Use Default Settings is selected.

itns3001.content:
You can create playlists of certain types of music, songs with certain ratings, or songs that match other rules you specify. iTunes can update these playlists automatically.

For example, you could create a Smart Playlist that’s no more than 5 gigabytes (GB) in size and includes your most highly rated jazz songs. Or you could create a Smart Playlist of songs by a particular artist. When you import a new CD from that artist, the songs can be added automatically to the Smart Playlist.

To create a Smart Playlist:

  • Choose File > New Smart Playlist.

A Smart Playlist icon has a gear on it.

To change a Smart Playlist, select it and choose File > Edit Smart Playlist.

itns3010.content:
To play many purchases from the iTunes Store, you must authorize your computer using your iTunes Store account and password. (Authorization helps protect the copyrights of the purchased items.)

You can have up to five authorized computers (Macintosh, Windows, or both) at a time. To play a purchased item on a sixth computer, you need to deauthorize another one. An iPod, iPhone, iPad, or Apple TV doesn’t count as a computer.

You can authorize or deauthorize a computer at any time. Be sure to deauthorize a computer before you sell it or give it away.

Here are ways to authorize or deauthorize a computer:

  • To authorize a computer to play iTunes Store purchases, choose Store > Authorize Computer.

  • To deauthorize a computer, choose Store > Deauthorize Computer.

  • To deauthorize a computer to play spoken programs purchased from the Audible website, choose Advanced > Deauthorize Audible Account.

  • If you forgot to deauthorize a computer you no longer own, and you have five authorized computers, you can deauthorize all your authorized computers at once. You can use this method once a year.

    Choose Store > View My Account, and then click Deauthorize All. If you don’t see this option, it’s because you don’t have five authorized computers.

If you have trouble deauthorizing a computer, visit the website below.

See also

itns3090.content:
iTunes can create a playlist of random songs from your library or a playlist. An iTunes DJ playlist continually updates itself (it’s a “live mix”), and you can edit it at any time.

While you’re playing an iTunes DJ mix, you can use the Remote application on your iPhone, iPod touch, or iPad to request songs. You can also allow guests to request songs to play, and to vote on songs. Voting affects when and whether a song plays.

You can download the Remote application from the iTunes Store.

To create an iTunes DJ live mix:

  1. Below Playlists, click iTunes DJ.

  2. To select a specific playlist (instead of your library) for the live mix, choose an option from the Source pop-up menu at the bottom of the iTunes window.

  3. To change the number of played or upcoming songs you want to see in the playlist, click Settings.

  4. To change the order or add new songs, drag them. To delete a song, select it and press Delete.

To hide the iTunes DJ playlist:

  1. Choose iTunes > Preferences, and click General.

  2. Deselect iTunes DJ in the General pane.

To allow guests to request and vote on songs:

  1. On the left side of the iTunes window, click iTunes DJ (under Playlists).

  2. Click Settings (at the bottom of the window).

  3. In the iTunes DJ Settings window, select “Allow guests to request songs with Remote for iPhone and iPod touch.”

  4. To allow guests to vote on songs, select Enable Voting.

  5. To require guests to enter a password before they can make a request or vote, select “Require password” and type the password.

  6. To customize the message guests see when they join your party, type in the Welcome Message area.

To request songs using Remote:

  1. On your iPhone, iPod touch, or iPad, tap Settings and choose the host’s Wi-Fi network.

  2. Tap Remote to open the Remote application.

  3. Tap the iTunes DJ name to join the party. If the host has required a password, type it.

  4. To request a song, tap “Request a Song” and then tap the song.

  5. To vote on a song in the iTunes DJ mix, tap it and then tap Like It or Dislike It.

See also
Play songs in your iTunes library

itns32504.content:
The first time you connect your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad to your computer, iTunes asks for your permission to collect and analyze diagnostic and usage information from your device.

Apple uses the information to improve the quality and performance of its products and services. The information may include details about hardware and operating system specifications, performance statistics, and data about how you use your device and applications.

Diagnostic and usage information is collected only with your explicit consent, and is submitted anonymously to Apple. None of the collected information identifies you personally. Personal data is either not logged at all, or is removed from any reports before they’re sent to Apple.

To select reporting options when you set up your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad:

  1. Connect your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad to your computer and follow the onscreen instructions to set up your device.

    During setup, a message appears, asking your permission to send diagnostic and usage information about your device to Apple.

  2. Do one of the following:

    • To allow iTunes to send information automatically, select “Do not ask me again,” and then click Agree.

    • If you want iTunes to ask for your permission each time it sends information to Apple, deselect “Do not ask me again,” and then click Agree.

    • If you don’t want your device information sent to Apple, select “Do not ask me again,” and then click Disagree.

To change your device’s reporting options:

  1. Connect your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad to your computer.

  2. In iTunes, hold down the Control key on your keyboard while you click your device (below Devices).

  3. Choose Reset Warnings from the menu that appears.

    The next time iTunes asks you for permission to send information, follow step 2 in the above section to set your reporting options.

Reports are submitted to Apple using your Internet connection. Your computer and device keep the information for one month after a report is generated, and then delete the information.

For more information, see:

Apple Customer Privacy Policy

itns8e44d445.content:
When you become a member of iTunes Ping, you can follow your favorite artists and other music fans, and other people can follow you. You can also invite friends to iTunes Ping via email.

iTunes Ping recommends artists and people you may be interested in following. You can also search for artists and other members. When you follow an artist, you can see their recent activity in iTunes Ping, such as music they enjoy or an announcement about an upcoming release.

If you want to require your approval to be followed, see Create an iTunes Ping profile for instructions.

To search for people and artist profiles:

When you sign up for iTunes Ping, iTunes shows you your Recent Activity page to make it easy to start following people, and recommends artists and featured people. You can search for friends by name, or invite friends to iTunes Ping via email.

To search for friends by name:

  1. In iTunes Ping, click People.

  2. Type a name in the search field that appears on the page, and press Return.

    Your search results appear in a new page. You can view All, or you can view by Artists or People.

You can also find artists and people by clicking Featured Artists or Featured People.

To follow an artist or person:

  1. In iTunes Ping, search for the person or artist you want to follow.

  2. Click Follow. If the person requires approval to be followed, a request is sent.

To stop following an artist or person:

  1. In iTunes Ping, click People.

  2. Click the People I Follow tab to see a list of people you follow.

  3. Select the artist or person you want to remove from the list, and click Stop Following.

To stop a person from following you:

  1. In iTunes Ping, click People.

  2. Click the People Who Follow Me tab.

  3. Select the person you want to remove from the list, and click Remove.

To accept or ignore follow requests:

  1. In iTunes Ping, click the People tab.

  2. Click the Follow Requests tab to see a list of requests.

  3. Select a request, and choose Confirm or Ignore.

If you choose Confirm, a notification is sent back to the requestor. If you choose Ignore, no notification is sent.

To Invite your friends to iTunes Ping via email:

  • In iTunes Ping, click People, click Invite, and follow the onscreen instructions.

itns8e44d530.name: Connect to artists and people with iTunes Ping

itns8e44d6e4.content:
Watch the movie (about 2 minutes)

Follow Music and People with Ping

iTunes Ping makes it easy to follow your favorite artists and friends or connect with the world's most passionate music fans, and discover the music everyone is talking about, listening to, and downloading.

You can use iTunes Ping to read real-time updates from the people you follow, see photos and watch videos posted by your favorite artists, discover the music your friends are buying, and find out who's going to a concert near you.

You can also tell your followers about the music you like and recommend, have iTunes Ping notify them whenever you write a review, and comment on their updates.

To use iTunes Ping, you need to create a free profile using an Apple ID.
itns8e44d6e4.name: iTunes Ping overview
itns8e44d6e4.summary: iTunes Ping makes it easy to follow your favorite artists and connect with other music fans.

itns8e44d7cf.content:
Before using iTunes Ping to follow artists and other music fans, you need to set up a free profile in iTunes Ping. Make sure you’re signed into the iTunes Store.

To create an iTunes Ping profile:

  1. In iTunes, click Ping (below Store).

  2. Click “Turn on iTunes Ping,” and enter your Apple ID information.

  3. Follow the onscreen instructions to accept terms and conditions, add your profile information, and set privacy settings.

    To require approval before someone can follow you, select “Require approval to follow me.”
itns8e44d7cf.name: Create an iTunes Ping profile
itns8e44d7cf.summary: To use iTunes Ping, you need to create a free profile in the iTunes Store.

itns8e44def4.content:
iTunes Ping lets you follow the activities that you or the artists or people you follow create in iTunes Ping or the iTunes Store.

For example, when you purchase an album or song in the iTunes Store, your purchase activity appears to your followers in iTunes Ping. Or if your favorite artist posts a comment or has a concert your friends are going to, you can find out all about it in iTunes Ping as well.

To view and manage activities:

  • In iTunes Ping, click Recent Activity to see a list of all recent activities. For each activity, you can do any of the following:

    • Flag an item as inappropriate.

    • Like an item.

    • Comment on an item.

    • Post an item.

To follow concerts, find tickets, and let friends know you’re going:

  • On the Recent Activity page, click Concerts. A list of concerts and tour information for the artists you follow appears.

    • To find tickets, click Find Tickets.

    • To let your followers know you’re going to the concert, click I’m Going.

To notify your followers that you like a song or album in the iTunes Store:

  1. In iTunes, click iTunes Store (below Store).

  2. Find the song or album you want to notify your followers about.

  3. Click the Like button for the item.

    Your iTunes Ping followers will see that you like the song or album in their Recent Activity feed.

To post a song or album to iTunes Ping:

  1. In iTunes, click iTunes Store (below Store).

  2. Find the song or album you want to post.

  3. Click the Post button for the item.

  4. Type any comments you want to appear in the post, and click Submit.

    Your iTunes Ping followers will see your post in their Recent Activity feed.

To review an album:

  1. In iTunes, click iTunes Store (below Store).

  2. Go to the album page for the album you want to review.

  3. Click "Write a Review” (below Customer Reviews).

  4. Type the title of the album, and write your review.

  5. Click Submit.

    Your review is submitted to the iTunes Store, and your followers will see your review, and a link to it on the album page, in their Recent Activity feed.
